node.title: Spring Date Set for Broadway Revival of ‘For Colored Girls’
node.alt: Camille A. Brown will create a fully reimagined production of “for colored girls who have considered suicide/when the rainbow is enuf” this spring.
node.description: Ntozake Shange’s choreopoem begins performances in March at the Booth Theater, home to the original 1976 production.
node.content: ["The previously announced Broadway production of Ntozake Shange\u2019s 1976 \u201cfor colored girls who have considered suicide/when the rainbow is enuf,\u201d directed by Camille A. Brown, now has an opening date. After beginning previews on March 4, 2022, the show will open on March 24 at the Booth Theater, producers announced Monday.", "Brown, who will be making her Broadway directorial debut, choreographed the director Leah C. Gardiner\u2019s well-received 2019 revival of Shange\u2019s choreopoem for the Public Theater. But this Broadway production, which Brown will also choreograph, will be fully reimagined.", "\u201cOf all the shows to be given as an opportunity to debut as a first-time Broadway director and choreographer, \u201cfor colored girls \u2026\u201d feels like a gift,\u201d Brown said in a news release Monday. \u201cI\u2019m thrilled that I\u2019ve been entrusted to combine all the parts of myself \u2014 dance, music and theater arts \u2014 to shape and share this timeless story again with the world.\u201d", "Shange\u2019s landmark work incorporates poetry, song and dance to tell the stories of seven women who are identified only by the hues of the dresses they wear. In his review of the recent Off Broadway revival, Ben Brantley detailed some of the show\u2019s history as it made its way from bars and clubs to become \u201cone of the most unexpected theater hits to emerge from the chaotic 1970s.\u201d He added: \u201cShange\u2019s free-form text was neither linear nor literal in its depiction of Black women struggling to claim their own voices from a society that had either ignored or actively silenced them.\u201d", "Shange has inspired many, and her death in 2018 prompted a renewed interest in her work. The playwright Keenan Scott II has credited Shange\u2019s \u201cfor colored girls\u201d as an initial inspiration for his debut Broadway production, \u201cThoughts of a Colored Man.\u201d He recently said that in college, a class screening of the Shange work was his first \u2014 and essentially his only \u2014 exposure to theater by Black playwrights at the time.", "Brown is a Tony Award nominee for her choreography in \u201cChoir Boy.\u201d She most recently choreographed and co-directed the Terence Blanchard opera \u201cFire Shut Up in My Bones,\u201d which debuted at the Metropolitan Opera in September. The Times\u2019s dance critic Gia Kourlas said Brown\u2019s step number for the opera \u201cstops the show in its tracks.\u201d", "Casting will be announced at a later date."]
